awd_titl_txt: New Applications of Combinatorics to Representation Theory and Schubert Calculus
awd_abstract_narration:
The main goal of the research is to use combinatorial structures and methods in order to perform computations in algebra (more specifically, representation theory), geometry, topology, and number theory; hidden connections between various areas are also revealed in this process. Combinatorics studies various discrete structures (such as permutations, partially ordered sets, and graphs), which are well suited for encoding complex mathematical objects and for the related computations. Representation theory is a fundamental tool for studying symmetry, by realizing the elements of abstract groups/algebras as linear transformations (of some vector spaces). The PI studies representations of Lie algebras and quantum groups, which have many applications to physics, such as calculating the probability of a particle system being in a given state at a particular time. In geometry, the PI focuses on Schubert calculus, which has its origins in enumerative geometry (e.g., counting the lines or planes satisfying a number of generic intersection conditions), but is currently related to modern areas such as quantum cohomology. Some of the models developed by the PI have been or will be implemented in the open source computer algebra system SAGE.

The proposed research consists of the following main projects, to be pursued with several collaborators. (1) The PI will extend his work on uniform combinatorial models for Kirillov-Reshetikhin (KR) crystals of affine Lie algebras from the single column KR crystals to the arbitrary ones. (2) Uniform combinatorial formulas are sought for the (non-metaplectic and metaplectic) Iwahori Whittaker functions, which are a basic tool in the theory of automorphic forms. Connections with Schubert calculus will also be investigated. (3) The combinatorics of the geometric Satake correspondence (realizing geometrically the irreducible representations of reductive groups) is studied via a combinatorial decomposition of Lusztig's q-analogue of the Weyl character. (4) In Schubert calculus, the PI has several projects related to various cohomologies of generalized flag varieties. In particular, an extension of Schubert calculus beyond K-theory is pursued based on the so-called Kazhdan-Lusztig Schubert classes in hyperbolic cohomology (which gives a stalk version of the elliptic cohomology of Ginzburg-Kapranov-Vasserot); these classes were defined by the PI in previous joint work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An important part of my work is concerned with using combinatorial structures and methods for computations related to the representation theory of Lie algebras. Representation theory is a fundamental tool for studying symmetry by realizing the elements of abstract groups/algebras as linear transformations (of some vector spaces). Lie algebras are an important class of algebras with many applications to physics. They have interesting deformations, called quantum groups, which depend on a parameter q, interpreted as physical temperature. At "zero temperature", the representations of quantum groups are encoded by certain colored directed graphs called crystals. 

Representations of quantum groups, and therefore crystals, have important applications to statistical mechanics. In this area, a physical system is modeled by a grid graph with weights associated to vertices (which represent atoms or particles) and a given number of states for the edges (which represent the bonds). The probability of the system being in any given state at a particular time, and hence the properties of the system, are determined by certain statistical sums. These can be computed as sums over certain crystals of the so-called energy function at a crystal vertex.

The graph in the figure is an affine crystal (it corresponds to a certain representation of an affine Lie algebra). The energy is constant on the (vertices of the) 4 connected components determined by the edges labeled 1 and 2. For each edge labeled 0, except the last one in a sequence of such edges, there is a decrease by 1 of the energy. So the energy on the 4 components is 0, -1, -2, -3, from left to right. As such graphs can be very large, it is more efficient to compute the energy only in terms of combinatorial data associated to the vertices (in the figure, we use fillings of diagrams with numbers). With my co-authors, I developed a very general combinatorial model (data associated to the vertices), called the quantum alcove model, in terms of which we can explicitly construct the crystal edges and calculate the energy at each vertex. 

During the period of this grant, I continued the development of the quantum alcove model for affine crystals. I also worked on various applications of crystals. 

An interesting project in the combinatorial representation theory of Lie algebras on which I worked recently is related to a long-standing problem in this area, namely the computation of the so-called Kostka-Foulkes polynomials beyond Lie type A. These polynomials record an important grading of the pieces/subspaces into which an irreducible representation of a Lie algebra splits, and are also related to the energy function mentioned above in type A. We formulated a solid conjecture about this relationship beyond type A, and we are making progress towards its proof. 

Another important part of my work involves applying combinatorial methods to computations in an area of algebraic geometry/topology called Schubert calculus, which involves geometric objects called flag varieties/manifolds. Classical Schubert calculus, which goes back to the second half of the 19th century, is concerned with enumerating geometric objects satisfying prescribed incidence constraints. The simplest non-trivial example is: given 4 lines in general position in 3-space, how many lines meet all of them? (The answer is 2.) The basic questions in enumerative geometry were reformulated in the framework of flag manifolds, and thus reduced to multiplication formulas in some associated algebraic structures (cohomology rings). 

With my collaborators, I worked on two extensions of Schubert calculus in which the usual structures in this area (ordinary cohomology and K-theory) are replaced with more refined algebraic structures recording additional geometric information, namely quantum K-theory (a deformation of K-theory) and elliptic cohomology. 

The combinatorial structures developed in my work, including the quantum alcove model mentioned above, were used by several researchers, and were implemented in the computer algebra system Sage.

During the period of this grant, I published 14 papers in top mathematical journals and two edited collections; some of the journals are: Advances in Mathematics -- 2 papers, Selecta Mathematica, Algebra and Number Theory, International Mathematical Research Notices, Journal of the Institute of Mathematics of Jussieu, and Journal of Algebra -- 2 papers. I also posted 4 other papers on arXiv.

The grant support was crucial for my interactions with existing and potential collaborators, by hosting 6 of them and visiting 11. 

In spite of the serious disruptions caused by the COVID pandemic, the support from my NSF grant enabled me to disseminate my research by presenting 12 papers in national and international conferences, as well as by giving 12 seminar/colloquium talks at universities in the US and abroad. 

During the period of this grant, I supervised 5 PhD students, 2 postdoctoral researchers, and 2 undergraduate research projects. I offered my students support from my NSF grant, as Research Assistants and for conference travel. 

I also organized several mathematical events.
